label.label: Bombardier Inc.
label.involvement: Held multiple leadership roles including Vice President Strategic Initiatives, President of Bombardier's International Group, President and Chief Operating Officer.
label.reasoning: Long-term leadership positions at a major corporation indicate significant career commitment.

supporting_quotes: He then joined Bombardier Inc. in 1995, and as vice president Strategic Initiatives, was recognised as Canada's Top 40 under 40 in 1998.
events.notes: Clear linkage between time, organization, and role.

quotes: Greenhill began his career at McKinsey & Company in 1987.
He then joined Bombardier Inc. in 1995, and as vice president Strategic Initiatives, was recognised as Canada's Top 40 under 40 in 1998.
He then joined Bombardier Inc. in 1995, and as vice president Strategic Initiatives, was recognised as Canada's Top 40 under 40 in 1998.
In 2001, he became president of Bombardier's International Group and held that role until 2004.
In 2001, he became president of Bombardier's International Group and held that role until 2004.

In 2002, he co-founded the Banff Forum, one of Canada’s preeminent public policy forums that brings together every year 200 leaders from across Canada and leading thinkers from around the world to share their knowledge, enhance their leadership skills, build national networks, and discuss and debate the most pressing issues facing Canada today.
In 2004, Greenhill joined the International Development Research Centre as Senior Visiting Executive, producing a critical account of Canada's global engagement 'Making A Difference?'.
In 2005, Greenhill was appointed president of the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA), and Deputy Minister for International Cooperation during the 27th Canadian Ministry.
Food aid was 100% untied by April 2008.
Greenhill was also engaged in Haiti, unveiling a 5-year $520 million commitment in 2006.
In 2006, United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan named Greenhill to the High-level Panel on United Nations Systemwide Coherence.

label.label: World Economic Forum
label.involvement: Held the position of Managing Director and Chief Business Officer.
label.reasoning: Leadership role in a globally influential organization indicates significant career commitment.

supporting_quotes: In 2008, Greenhill joined the Geneva-based World Economic Forum (WEF) as Managing Director and Chief Business Officer.
events.notes: Clear linkage between time, organization, role, and location.

quotes: In 2008, Greenhill joined the Geneva-based World Economic Forum (WEF) as Managing Director and Chief Business Officer.
In 2014, Greenhill returned to Montreal to found Global Canada, a multistakeholder initiative committed to improving Canada's global impact.
In September 2015 Greenhill co-authored 'Assessing Canada's Global Engagement Gap'.

Greenhill has a BA in political science from the University of Alberta (1984), where he was twice the university's Student Union president, being the youngest ever at 20 years old and elected to this position during a crisis that threatened to bankrupt the organization.
He has an MA in international history from the London School of Economics (1986), and an MBA from INSEAD (1987).
He has an MA in international history from the London School of Economics (1986), and an MBA from INSEAD (1987).
